abstracts.cdata!:
The Tocantins Rural Infrastructure
            Project seeks to improve traffic conditions, and
            transportation costs, to in turn further consolidate the
            policy on appropriate uses of the State's natural
            resources. In light of the project's impending road
            construction, this Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) reviews the
            Constitution's articles relevant to indigenous peoples
            rights, as well as the Regulation of the Indigenous National
            Foundation (FUNAI) (Annexes I and II), to establish
            procedures for project implementation, avoiding as possible,
            or minimizing, adverse impacts on the lives of indigenous
            populations. It is noted that legislation stipulates a
            radius of ten kilometers should protect indigenous reserves,
            and, activities potentially endangering biodiversity, should
            abide by the norms set by the National Council for the
            Environment (CONAMA). However, taking into consideration the
            above mentioned laws and regulations, an environmental
            assessment on various alternatives, comparative analyses for
            the design of road networks, and local consultations, the
            alternative proposed states that, the new road segment
            traversing indigenous land, would provide the opportunity
            for land restoration of vast areas previously subjected to
            agricultural, and livestock practices, and, its proximity to
            the city of Nazare - currently isolated - would provide
            positive social, and economic benefits to the region.
